channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Greek Patience With Austerity Nears Its Limit
item.description: The vast majority of Greeks are still experiencing the hardships of reform, with little evidence that the measures are working.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Goods being distributed at a social center in Nea Ionia, Greece. Last year, the national unemployment rate reached 27 percent, and the vast majority of out-of-work Greeks have not had a paycheck in more than two years.

item.title: Europe Braces for Economic Fallout as Greece Heads to Early Elections
item.description: The Greek Parliament on Monday failed to avert an early general election, reviving the toxic debate over austerity as the way to cure the continent’s economic woes.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS and JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Antonis Samaras said he would ask President Karolos Papoulias to dissolve Parliament to make way for early elections.

item.title: Guards Retreat in London, but Just a Bit
item.description: At some residences for the Queen’s family, the guards have moved behind gates, and farther from tourists, because of concerns about terrorism.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: Guardsmen now stand behind the gates of Clarence House in London.

item.title: Responses to Ferry Fire Are Criticized
item.description: The Italian Navy on Sunday rescued 427 people evacuated from a burning ship, and questions quickly arose about the response of the stricken ship’s crew.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Passengers disembarked with rescuers Monday in Bari, Italy, after being evacuated from a burning ferry.

item.title: World Briefing: Ukraine: Leader to Attend Peace Talks
item.description: President Petro O. Poroshenko said Monday that he was planning to meet in Kazakhstan on Jan. 15 with the leaders of Russia, Germany and France to discuss a peace settlement for eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Ebola Case Reported in Glasgow
item.description: A woman who had been working in Sierra Leone was being treated Monday for Ebola in a Glasgow hospital.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: World Briefing: Cameroon: Airstrikes Target Militants
item.description: Cameroon’s government said Monday that it had begun airstrikes against Nigerian Islamic extremists to dislodge about 1,000 fighters who seized the Achigachia military base on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: China Adds New Barrier To Gmail
item.description: The government appears to have blocked the ability of people in China to access their Gmail accounts through third-party email clients.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG KIKI ZHAO and CONOR DOUGHERTY
item.media:description: A phone in China with a Gmail app. Blocking of Gmail service in China began on Friday.

item.title: South America Memo: An Economic Boom Recedes, but South America Might Avert the Bust
item.description: Governments of Brazil, Peru and Venezuela are seen as less likely than before to load up on debt and ignore danger signs.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil worker near Lake Maracaibo in Venezuela. Last year, the country received 95 percent of its export income from petroleum.

item.title: Turkey Strengthens Rights of Syrian Refugees
item.description: New ID cards will grant access to basic health care and education, while a separate proposal would allow conditional work permits.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: How Ebola Roared Back
item.description: For a fleeting moment last spring, the epidemic sweeping West Africa might have been stopped. But the opportunity to control the virus, which has now caused more than 7,800 deaths, was lost.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By KEVIN SACK, SHERI FINK, PAM BELLUCK and ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph S. Gbembo at a cemetery for Ebola victims in Foya, Liberia. His mother and three other relatives are buried there. The Gbembos lost 17 family members to Ebola in cases stretching from Sierra Leone to Liberia’s capital, Monrovia.

item.title: Malaysians Are Shaken by Loss of 3rd Jet in Year
item.description: At AirAsia’s hub in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, passengers and relatives of people about to board flights expressed skepticism over official bulletins about Flight 8501.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Relatives of passengers on AirAsia Flight 8501 awaiting news of the airliner at the airport in Surabaya, Indonesia on Monday.

item.title: Pakistani Judge Upholds Bail for Suspect in Mumbai Attacks
item.description: The Islamabad High Court said that Zaki-ur-Rehman Lakhvi, who is accused of masterminding the 2008 Mumbai attacks, should be able to win his release.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Seen in 2008 in Muzaffarabad, Pakistan, Zaki-ur-Rehman Lakhvi, a senior commander with Lashkar-e-Taiba who is accused of directing the attacks in the Indian city of Mumbai that year.

item.title: A View From Abroad: Why Greece’s New Crisis Isn’t Spreading to the Rest of Europe
item.description: This time around, financial markets seem to view Greece’s problems as limited to Greece. That’s great, unless the markets are wrong.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL IRWIN
item.media:description: Alexis Tsipras, the opposition leader and head of the Syriza party, leaving the Parliament building after the last round of a presidential vote in Athens on Monday.

item.title: Fire Damages Another Islamic Site in Sweden
item.description: A room in southern Sweden used as a worship center was destroyed by fire, the second instance of suspected arson against Muslims in less than a week.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Letter From Europe: Russians See Costlier Food as No Crisis
item.description: Familiar with economic crises, consumers are barely ruffled by the current devaluation of the ruble, higher prices in shops and scarcity of imported goods.
item.dc:creator: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: Israeli Military Kills Palestinian Teenager in West Bank
item.description: The military said its forces opened fire after a group hurling rocks on a main road failed to heed a call to stop and disregarded warning shots.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Critic's Notebook: In Haiti, Battling Disease With Open-Air Clinics
item.description: Two new clinics in Haiti for treating cholera and tuberculosis could be models for other struggling countries that lack resources for high-end Western-style hospitals.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

item.title: Court Moves Up Verdict Announcement for Putin Critic
item.description: The abrupt date change raised the possibility that Aleksei A. Navalny, who rose to prominence as an anti-corruption activist, would be handed a lengthy prison term just before New Year’s Eve.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Russian opposition activist Alexei Navalny, right, waits for a start of a trial in a courtroom in Moscow, Russia, on December 19.

item.title: Japan and South Korea Vow to Share Intelligence About North via the U.S.
item.description: Under the pact, the sharing of classified information will be limited to North Korea’s missile and nuclear weapons programs.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Japan’s vice foreign minister, Akitaka Saiki, left, and the South Korean diplomat Cho Tae-yong, in Seoul. The two nations agreed to share military information about North Korea.
